Author: arkensor
Content: Not sure if I followed the conversation correctly. But as general info, network variables are optimized as much as they can be. they are all put into a byte stream and not send as individual variables. so you can send multiple bools in the place of one int. If an int only requires 5 bits due to the quantization limits given then it will only take up 5 bits. However there are minimum sizes for the network sync packets and you have no control over what other data is being sent, so you can not make any assumption on the exact message size you will produce. Regardless you should try to use as little space as possible to increase the chance of your data fitting into an existing space so no additional bytes are used. e.g. if you know your integer will only ever have values between 0 and 100 ... then limit it to that range. Don't make the system think it could potentially be int.max. If you have lots of netsync variables this can have a meaningful impact.

Author: arkensor
Content:
I would recommend to use a synced context like the game time, or simulation step number to tell clients when they will be allowed to use it again. you only need to set this value once on use to `now + 10 minutes` and then double check the action on the server side if that 10 minutes have passed since the last use. The client could simply bypass any local restrictions.

Or as @Wardog suggested simply set the bool "usable" true or false on the server and have a timer running every time the action is successfully executed. That should work out fine if you do not have too many of the items - otherwise the server gets bloated with running timers.

Author: osodirty
Content:
@TheGiantSwede For starters, stop using `const` in this context. It means "constant" as in you cannot change it after it's defined.

2nd, "multiple declarations"  This means you're declaring the variable more than once. You only need to declare the type (string in this instance) once. You can reuse/redefine it as many times as you'd like, but you can only type it out as `string DEFAULT_CHARACTER_NAME = "text goes here";` once. From then on, you just use `DEFAULT_CHARACTER_NAME = "text goes here";`
